awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T3:  Innovations for Sustainable Food, Energy, And Water Supplies In Intensively Cultivated Regions: Integrating Technologies, Data, And Human Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
To keep pace with the demands of a growing global population, innovations are needed to meet the unprecedented challenge of producing more food in intensively cultivated regions with less energy and lower environmental impacts. In this project, researchers from the biophysical, socioeconomic, and computational sciences investigate two types of innovations using data from the northern U.S. Corn Belt. First, a novel oilseed crop, winter camelina, is being studied for its potential incorporation into existing corn-soybean rotations to produce a new supply of biodiesel energy while lowering water resource impacts and creating positive ecological benefits. Second, emerging systems of sustainability certification are being studied for their potential to lead to broad-scale adoption of this new cropping system. Detailed computational models are being evaluated and applied for systems-level assessments of two innovations: developing novel approaches to influence beneficial land use, and accounting for energy and environmental impacts within food supply chains. Because of the importance of the project results on the local economy, outreach activities are targeted towards the rural community, policy makers, the general public, and local watershed planners. Although this project focuses on the Northern Corn Belt, the approaches used in the research could be adopted to achieve beneficial outcomes for food, energy, and water systems elsewhere. 

This research project I scomprised of four overlapping and interdependent research teams. The biophysical research team conducts cropping systems studies of corn-soybean in rotation with winter camelina at two Minnesota research stations. Experimental treatments vary by winter timing of planting and harvest and fertilization rates. Meteorological data along with soil, water, and crops data is being collected to develop management strategies for producers and to calibrate and evaluate the crop models that will be used. The socioeconomic research team collects data from surveys and randomized control trials to study the forces determining whether, and by whom, new cropping systems are likely to be adopted under different policy and market conditions. Of particular interest is the role of incentives from certification programs, including the feedback effects of using producer data for peer benchmarking. The data science team applies novel deep learning computational approaches to identify crops, including winter cover crops, from satellite imagery. Study plots for the biophysical plots provides training data for crop identification and the final statewide datasets are being incorporated in the socioeconomic analysis. Finally, the integrated modeling team develops a suite of connected modeling tools to quantify systems-level outcomes. These simulations shed light on the feasibility and impacts of innovations in the food-energy-water system under different scenarios, including spatial patterns and the role of socio-economic drivers.

por.por_cntn:
Innovations are needed to meet the growing global demands for food and renewable energy while reducing the environmental impacts from agricultural production. This project investigated innovative cropping systems that incorporate winter crops into traditional rotations. The project generated new insights on these systems, explaining some of the complex interactions that lead to variation in system performance. These insights also suggest promising avenues to maximize the benefits of the system in the future.

Adding a winter crop to existing rotations changes the ways that inputs of water, nutrients, and energy flow through the cultivated landscape, which in turn alters crop production and environmental impacts. A winter crop provides vegetative cover in late autumn and early spring, transpiring excess water and taking up nutrients that would otherwise be lost to the environment. Winter cover crops, which are terminated at the time of spring planting, have been shown to reduce nutrient losses and improve soil health, but they provide no source of revenue for farmers to offset establishment costs. More recent innovations include winter-hardy oilseed crops such as camelina, which can be harvested for cash value as the primary ingredient in advanced biofuel or food oil. 

Field research in this project examined the winter camelina system across multiple locations and years. Field data revealed that in dry years, reduced soil available water limits the establishment and growth of a new crop when it is planted around the time of previous crop maturity. Winter camelina was also found to be responsive to nitrogen (N), with N fertilization rates positively affecting above-ground biomass and grain yields. These results suggest that farmers growing camelina would have an incentive to increase N fertilization rates, raising the risks of surplus residual soil N that could be lost to the environment. 

A life-cycle analysis model assessed the cradle to farm-gate impacts of the winter camelina system on fossil energy consumption, greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and particulate air emissions. The winter camelina system was found to increase fossil energy consumption and related emissions due to increased input intensity. On-farm activities such as tillage, harvest, and input application consumed the greatest amount of fossil energy. Consistent with other research on food oil production systems, the agricultural production stage dominated supply chain GHG emissions, with transportation and processing comprising a much smaller proportion of emissions. 

An integrated economic-biophysical model was applied to assess the water quality impacts of cropping system changes at a watershed scale. The model optimized the locations within a watershed where the traditional maize-soybean cropping system could be converted to alternative management practices including winter cover crops and perennial biomass crops. The optimized pattern of practices varied within a watershed and across years, reflecting the impacts of spatially isolated but locally intense precipitation events. These model outcomes demonstrate the importance of interannual weather variability on water quality in midwestern agricultural watersheds.

The biophysical model highlighted the importance of spatial placement of conservation practices. Data science work in the project developed improved methods for crop identification from remote sensing data, which will provide more accurate datasets for future modeling and precision targeting of practices. In particular, predictive models were developed that yielded accurate predictions even with highly noisy and incomplete labels in training data. These models were applied to improve the accuracy of crop identification in pixel based maps.

Socioeconomic research examined the barriers and opportunities for farmers to adopt new cropping systems. Primary data were collected from farmers in selected study watersheds through focus groups and multiple waves of surveys. Analysis of the data revealed that most farmers were unfamiliar with cover crops overall, consistent with observed low cover crop adoption rates. Familiarity and adoption were even lower for innovative winter crops like camelina. Farmers are concerned about the costs of cover crops, their impact on farm profitability, and other potential risks, especially with climate variability in the region.

While the project revealed numerous challenges, several findings suggest promising pathways for improving winter cropping systems. For example, the input competition between winter and summer crops arises primarily from the long growing seasons of maize and soybean, suggesting that camelina could be integrated more successfully into rotations with shorter season crops such as small grains or even maize and soybean varieties that mature earlier. Advancements in precision nutrient management can ensure that additional nitrogen applied to intensified systems will be used by crops and not become environmental residuals. Finally, the socioeconomic work will help resource professionals develop engagement and outreach programs based on an understanding of farmer beliefs and attitudes.
